citations.desc: Primary enclosures used to transport live birds.
citations.narrative:
On July 31st, 2024, 22 northern ground hornbills arrived at John F. Kennedy International Airport (Queens, New York)
from N’djili International Airport (Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo) on Kenya Airways (AWB# 760-50174180).
The birds in this shipment experienced over-crowding. Four crates contained 5 birds. One smaller crate contained 2 birds.
APHIS officials observed the following upon arrival:
- Birds had broken wing and tail feathers.
- All birds were unable to turn or move within their crates.
- Some birds were huddled under other birds within their crates.
Overcrowding during transit can predispose animals to elevated stress, injury, disease, and/or death. In this shipment of
birds, all northern ground hornbills had broken feathers. Primary enclosures used to transport live birds must be large
enough to ensure that each bird contained therein has sufficient space to turn about freely and to make normal postural
adjustments.

On July 31st, 2024, 22 northern ground hornbills arrived at John F. Kennedy International Airport (Queens, New York)
from N’djili International Airport (Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo) on Kenya Airways (AWB# 760-50174180).
APHIS officials observed the following upon arrival:
- Six birds displayed severely contracted tendons and were either unable to walk at all or were lame.
- Three birds were lethargic/depressed and unable to stand.
- All birds were infested with lice and in poor body condition.
Based on an interview with the APHIS officials the illness listed above are likely chronic conditions, meaning the illness
were present prior to transportation. No documentation was present to indicate the birds were entering the United States
for veterinary care. Birds ill, injured or in physical distress, must not be transported in commerce, except to receive
veterinary care for the condition, for the comfort and well-being of the animals.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with cargo facility and airline representatives.
n

narrative:
3.162(e)  Critical
   
Primary enclosures used to transport live birds. 
On July 31st, 2024, 22 northern ground hornbills arrived at John F. Kennedy International Airport (Queens, New York) 
from N’djili International Airport (Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo) on Kenya Airways (AWB# 760-50174180). 
 
The birds in this shipment experienced over-crowding. Four crates contained 5 birds. One smaller crate contained 2 birds. 
 
APHIS officials observed the following upon arrival: 
- Birds had broken wing and tail feathers.  
- All birds were unable to turn or move within their crates. 
- Some birds were huddled under other birds within their crates. 
 
Overcrowding during transit can predispose animals to elevated stress, injury, disease, and/or death. In this shipment of 
birds, all northern ground hornbills had broken feathers. Primary enclosures used to transport live birds must be large 
enough to ensure that each bird contained therein has sufficient space to turn about freely and to make normal postural 
adjustments. 
3.165(c)  Critical
   
Care in transit. 
On July 31st, 2024, 22 northern ground hornbills arrived at John F. Kennedy International Airport (Queens, New York) 
from N’djili International Airport (Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo) on Kenya Airways (AWB# 760-50174180). 
 
APHIS officials observed the following upon arrival: 
- Six birds displayed severely contracted tendons and were either unable to walk at all or were lame. 
- Three birds were lethargic/depressed and unable to stand. 
- All birds were infested with lice and in poor body condition. 
 
Based on an interview with the APHIS officials the illness listed above are likely chronic conditions, meaning the illness 
were present prior to transportation. No documentation was present to indicate the birds were entering the United States

for veterinary care. Birds ill, injured or in physical distress, must not be transported in commerce, except to receive 
veterinary care for the condition, for the comfort and well-being of the animals. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with cargo facility and airline representatives.
